3.13.text:
I believe we need
more unreasonable people.

8.99.text: Actually, I'm hoping that after this talk,

11.52.text:
90% of this audience will want to become
more of an unreasonable person.

17.27.text:
I can see some of you frowning
here in the first row,

21.04.text:
because we were raised
in the Western culture,

23.21.text:
and especially us Dutchies,
to become reasonable people.

26.00.text:
Reason gives us
better careers, better lives.

29.57.text: I'm hoping to make you more unreasonable.

35.59.text:
I have a slide and we don't need
to read this all,

38.77.text:
but it means irrational,
not having the faculty of reason.

45.45.text: I got this from the free Wikipedia online.

48.44.text:
I found other synonyms like
silly, senseless, foolish.

52.02.text:
So I'm not convincing you
to be unreasonable yet, I realize,

55.06.text: but the reason I think it's important

58.05.text:
I'm going to show you with this next quote
by George Bernard Shaw,

64.10.text:
"The reasonable man
adapts himself to the world;

66.92.text:
the unreasonable one persists
in trying to adapt the world to himself.

72.04.text:
Therefore, all progress
depends on the unreasonable man."

79.67.text:
that the only way to create progress
is to be unreasonable.

82.52.text:
If we want to move forward in this world,
create a just and sustainable society,

86.38.text:
we need people that are willing
to break through the status quo,

89.38.text: and I fully support his view.

92.08.text: The first man on the Moon,

93.33.text:
the people who thought about that
were deemed totally unreasonable.

96.50.text:
The first people that wanted to create
the Internet were deemed unreasonable.

100.22.text:
Most innovation comes
from unreasonable people.

102.54.text: And personally, on a very small scale,

105.83.text:
I was called unreasonable
when I started WarChild.

109.29.text:
People felt that I was
a 24-year-old girl when I started,

112.69.text: I had no knowledge of war zones

115.30.text:
and no knowledge of aid organizations
or psycho-social projects,

119.35.text: so where would I find the funds?

122.09.text:
Today WarChild supports a million children
each year, in 13 war-torn countries.

135.11.text:
For me it's obvious
that unreasonable dreams can come true,

138.66.text: and that they can create progress.

141.79.text:
One of my unreasonable heroes
is Muhammad Yunus,

145.32.text: some of you will know him.

146.96.text:
His very unreasonable idea was
that you could provide unsecured loans

151.55.text:
to the poorest people
in the world, namely women.

154.56.text: Totally contrary to any banking system.

159.92.text:
to prove that you could build a business
and provide loans to these poor people,

164.63.text:
but today his model is copied all over
the world and it's called Microfinance.

170.25.text:
His own social enterprise Grameen
has already provided

173.46.text:
five billion dollars
to five million people

177.56.text:
helping them, giving them the chance
to free themselves from the poverty trap.

185.08.text:
So I believe there is a strong correlation
between unreasonable people and progress,

189.06.text:
especially if it is combined
with entrepreneurship,

196.37.text:
To me that's very obvious,
but I will touch on it

200.82.text:
The last 40 years we've had growth,
we've had huge accumulation of wealth,

205.87.text: but we haven't really been able to solve

208.47.text:
any of the major challenges
our world is faced with.

215.10.text: I can just name a few.

216.85.text:
We're depleting our natural
resources and raw materials

222.24.text:
There's 25 million people
in Africa that have HIV/AIDS.

227.16.text: A million of them die every year.

230.34.text:
We have one billion children
growing up in poverty.

234.05.text:
There's two billion kids in the world,
so every second child grows up in poverty.

239.84.text:
In 80% of the countries the divide
between rich and poor is growing

244.42.text: and Oxfam just published a report

248.83.text:
where they claim the 85 richest people
in this world own more wealth

254.76.text:
than the three and a half billion poorest,
which is half of the world's population.

264.59.text:
Poverty is closer than we think
because in the Netherlands,

267.46.text:
we have one million people
living below the poverty line.

270.81.text: Another two million people are lonely

272.76.text:
which I personally perceive
as a form of poverty.

276.17.text: There are hundreds of thousands of people

278.22.text:
that we put outside of our society
because they have a disability.

281.33.text:
And I could go on and on,
and I hope you agree with me

283.93.text:
that this situation is totally
unacceptable and also unsustainable.

290.24.text:
We urgently need to find
new solutions to these challenges.

295.38.text: I believe that these unreasonable people,

299.93.text:
play a key role in creating
that change, creating that progress.

307.35.text:
Because entrepreneurs
choose to see opportunities

312.65.text:
where other people
see intangible problems.

315.61.text:
They choose to swim against the stream,
to be unreasonable,

318.62.text:
to try new business models,
to create innovation.

322.77.text:
There are actually four characteristics
for a social enterprise I want to share.

326.60.text:
The first is every social entrepreneur
has a theory of change,

329.90.text:
something they want
to change in this world.

332.00.text:
Impact is their major driver.
Impact is what starts it all.

336.76.text:
They want to create that change
through a viable business model,

341.23.text:
through a market-based solution,
which means they don't want

344.36.text:
to be dependent on subsidies,
and grants, or on the government.

347.60.text:
They want to build a market-based
solution, which also means

350.54.text:
that they can scale that solution
if they make their business grow,

354.90.text: and it means the solution is sustainable.

357.77.text:
The most ambitious ones
want systemic change,

361.32.text:
want that change to be much bigger
than their own enterprise.

364.48.text: So let's look at the Netherlands.

366.19.text:
Do we have social entrepreneurs
in the Netherlands? Yes, we do.

369.22.text:
Quite a few very impressive ones,
and I'll tell you about a few of them.

372.75.text: I want to start with Text To Change.

375.88.text:
Text To Change is a social enterprise
started in 2007 by Bas and Hajo,

381.71.text:
and they wanted to use
mobile technology, SMS messaging,

387.24.text:
to reach the unreachable people
in the outskirts of the world,

391.33.text:
to bring development,
health care, education.

395.83.text:
First of all, you don't combine
mobile phones and healthcare

398.65.text:
and secondly, these people
in the outskirts of Africa

401.13.text:
would never be able to access
mobile phones - this was 2007.

404.36.text:
Today, 700 million people
in Africa have a mobile phone,

408.18.text: which is almost 60% of the continent,

410.51.text:
and people are expecting that next year
it's already going to be 85%.

417.25.text:
Text To Change has done
70 projects in 16 countries,

421.62.text: also in South America and Asia,

423.76.text:
and they have already sent
32 million text messages this year,

429.34.text: So what do these text messages do?

432.70.text:
in Uganda they made
an SMS quiz about HIV/AIDS.

437.26.text:
For prevention, to prevent transmission
and for people to raise awareness.

441.58.text:
40% of the people that took the quiz
had themselves tested at a local clinic.

450.57.text:
Another unreasonable entrepreneur,
who is actually from Utrecht,

455.00.text:
is called Sjoerd van der Maaden
from Specialisterren.

458.18.text:
His unreasonable idea was
he was going to to build a business

461.38.text: where he'd only employ autistic people.

464.75.text:
He believes autistic people
have enormous capacity

467.60.text:
if you look at what they can do
instead of look at what they can't do.

471.24.text:
There are 26,000 people
with a form of autism

473.87.text:
that are highly skilled
that sit at home without jobs.

477.16.text:
So he built a software testing company
because he knows, he has an autistic son,

481.79.text:
that people with this form
of autism are extremely good

485.11.text:
in concentration and details,
and have concrete focus.

487.95.text:
He has already proven that his staff,
his team, is better in testing software

492.60.text: than any other software testers around.

495.30.text:
This is a successful business
creating huge impact,

498.31.text:
giving people that were
formerly unemployed

500.54.text:
a chance to be part of our society
and build their own lives.

505.93.text:
As you can see these social enterprises
are very different

509.12.text:
than commercial enterprises,
or charities, or public institutions.

512.26.text:
They form a thriving new sector,
a sector that has continued to grow.

516.80.text:
Some of them are very ambitious;
they really want to change the system.

520.71.text: System change is not just about scale,

523.26.text:
system change is about changing
the hearts and minds of people.

528.46.text:
One of those potential system changers
from the Netherlands is Fairphone,

532.81.text:
by Bas van Abel, who actually
also lives in Utrecht.

539.33.text:
Bas wanted to change
the phones we are using.

544.27.text:
He was totally frustrated
by the fact that they are filled

547.16.text:
with raw materials from conflict areas,
mined often by children.

551.32.text:
They're being produced
in shady factories in Asia,

554.27.text:
they're totally customer unfriendly
because we can't customize them,

557.91.text: we can't even change the batteries anymore

560.18.text:
and they end up
in e-waste dumps in Africa.

563.66.text:
You can protest against it
and be an activist,

565.82.text:
or you can show
that it can be done differently.

570.07.text: The system change is in the fact

571.95.text:
that consumers are willing
to buy this phone.

574.25.text:
The fact that the consumers,
that we are willing to look

576.90.text:
at the different way
their products are made.

580.36.text:
Fairphone could potentially be
a revolution in the electronics industry.

586.76.text:
Of course, Bas was deemed
very unreasonable

592.22.text:
Another movement
that you must have all seen,

595.34.text:
and is a potential system changer,
is the share economy movement.

599.46.text:
The ventures that are trying
to help us understand

601.96.text:
that we should, instead of own things,
share things, create social cohesion

606.62.text:
instead of more material
wealth for ourselves.

610.96.text:
Think of SnappCar, a car sharing
platform, trying to explain

614.24.text: why should we all own our own car

616.29.text:
if it stands in front of our door
90% of the time doing nothing?

619.35.text: Why not share it with our neighbors?

621.12.text:
Last year 5,000 people in the Netherlands
were willing to share a car.

625.04.text:
This year 50,000 people in the Netherlands
were willing to share a car.

629.19.text:
This is a movement
that could really, really take off

637.34.text:
that sharing is a very basic principle
of all the social entrepreneurs,

641.42.text:
because they want to share
their models and create impact.

644.55.text:
So, it's not about creating
the biggest enterprise for themselves,

647.72.text:
it's about finding as many
other enterprises and people as they can

651.37.text:
to scale that impact,
to spread it like a virus.

655.88.text:
That is what inspires me so
about these entrepreneurs

658.37.text: and I hope it does you.

659.84.text:
I could tell you many more stories,
but there is no time.

662.67.text:
The interesting thing is
these social entrepreneurs,

665.76.text:
whether they want to change
locally, nationally, or internationally,

669.96.text:
are not professors in social impact
or all business school graduates,

674.55.text: they're people like you and me.

676.50.text:
They're people that are frustrated by
what they see in their direct environment

680.50.text: and they want to make a change.

682.64.text:
So everyone here could be
a social entrepreneur

685.05.text:
or could support
creating social enterprises.

690.92.text:
and another venture
called Social Impact Ventures,

693.63.text: both aimed at creating an ecosystem

695.60.text:
where social enterprises can thrive,
where they can grow,

699.30.text:
where they can create
more and more impact.

702.79.text:
I'm hoping more people
are willing to support that movement.

707.37.text:
There's a lot of entrepreneurs
in this room, I'm quite sure,

710.30.text:
but there are also investors,
teachers, consumers.

713.40.text: We all have the power to make a change.

716.11.text:
This is also the start
of a transformation of capitalism,

721.97.text:
where success will be measured
by the social impact we create.

728.74.text:
So please, if you go from here,
and tomorrow you need a software tester,

734.50.text:
think about calling
Specialisterren or AutiTalent

737.71.text:
or one of the ventures
that creates impact.

741.91.text:
And if you consider
buying a new car, don't.

744.63.text:
Go to SnappCar, MyWheels,
WeGo, or look at Peerby,

752.31.text:
If you pass by a shop
and look at what you see in front of you,

757.66.text:
please think of who suffered
to create these absurdly low prices

762.55.text: that you see on the products.

765.04.text:
And choose Tony's Chocolonely chocolate,
choose Moyi Cofee, choose the Fairphone,

770.88.text:
because I really think
everyone here can contribute

773.76.text:
if we just dare to be
